title: Senate advances border bill
content:
The emergency funding measure advanced with a 63-33 vote . Senate advances border bill
The Senate on Wednesday narrowly advanced an emergency funding measure to respond to the influx of unaccompanied migrant children crossing the southern border that has triggered a humanitarian crisis .
Despite the 63-33 vote , the $ 2.7 billion measure still faces significant barriers before it can win final passage in the Senate — let alone be reconciled with a drastically different bill that is emerging in the GOP-led House .
GOP senators who don ’ t support the Senate Democrats ’ package — which also includes funding for wildfire aid and for Israel ’ s Iron Dome missile defense system — lent their votes for the procedural vote in hopes of amending the measure more to their liking .
“ The folks in my state , particularly in the region of South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley , are watching and waiting and hoping that Washington will act to resolve this ongoing crisis , ” said Texas Sen. John Cornyn , the second-ranking Senate Republican who has pushed his own legislative fix to the crisis . “ But we can ’ t act unless the majority leader allows us to act . ”
Key Senate Republicans , including moderates and GOP lawmakers who wrote a sweeping immigration overhaul bill last year , have already said they oppose the Democratic measure . Their primary objection : It leaves intact a 2008 anti-trafficking law that , in practice , has made it more difficult to deport children from Central America now arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border .
Democrats also are expected to lose some of its own members . Louisiana Sen. Mary Landrieu , running for reelection in one of the most closely watched Senate races this year , has already ruled out backing the bill because she has “ little faith ” in the State Department to use its allocated funding to help stem violence in Central America .
Landrieu voted against the procedural vote on Wednesday , as did North Carolina Sen. Kay Hagan , another vulnerable red-state Democrat . She said in a statement after the vote that the Senate legislation falls short in tackling the root causes of the illegal migration and targeting the criminal trafficking groups that are transporting the minors .
Sen. Joe Manchin ( D-W.Va. ) , who voted to advance the legislation , said in a statement later Wednesday that he would reject the measure without “ major changes . ”
“ We need to include revisions to close loopholes in the 2008 immigration law so that there is the same deportation timetable for individuals from Central American countries as those from Mexico and Canada , ” Manchin said . “ The process should be the same for all of these countries . ”
The Democratic defections on Wednesday , as well as a high number of Republican opposition on the procedural vote , stoked some uncertainty in the chamber on as senators were still casting their ballots .
Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell ( R-Ky. ) , who opposes the Senate Democratic measure , initially voted to advance the bill . But once it looked like the legislation might collapse , he switched his vote to “ no . ”
A McConnell aide said when the outcome of the procedural vote looked murky , “ many of our members wanted to be on record in opposition to a bill that didn ’ t even include the minor reforms the president requested — not to mention any serious effort to secure the border . ”
Eleven Republicans ultimately voted with most Democrats to advance the supplemental .
Of the $ 2.7 billion in emergency funding , about $ 1.2 billion is for the Department of Health and Human Services and $ 1.1 billion is for agencies within the Department of Homeland Security , which primarily oversees border and immigration enforcement . About $ 300 million is designated for the State Department and $ 124 million is for the Justice Department .

The emergency funding measure advanced with a 63-33 vote. Senate advances border bill

The Senate on Wednesday narrowly advanced an emergency funding measure to respond to the influx of unaccompanied migrant children crossing the southern border that has triggered a humanitarian crisis.

And that wasn’t even the hard part.

Despite the 63-33 vote, the $2.7 billion measure still faces significant barriers before it can win final passage in the Senate — let alone be reconciled with a drastically different bill that is emerging in the GOP-led House.

( Also on POLITICO: Cantor's final days)

GOP senators who don’t support the Senate Democrats’ package — which also includes funding for wildfire aid and for Israel’s Iron Dome missile defense system — lent their votes for the procedural vote in hopes of amending the measure more to their liking.

“The folks in my state, particularly in the region of South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley, are watching and waiting and hoping that Washington will act to resolve this ongoing crisis,” said Texas Sen. John Cornyn, the second-ranking Senate Republican who has pushed his own legislative fix to the crisis. “But we can’t act unless the majority leader allows us to act.”

Key Senate Republicans, including moderates and GOP lawmakers who wrote a sweeping immigration overhaul bill last year, have already said they oppose the Democratic measure. Their primary objection: It leaves intact a 2008 anti-trafficking law that, in practice, has made it more difficult to deport children from Central America now arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border.

( Also on POLITICO: Is Obama changing his mind on nuclear arms?)

Democrats also are expected to lose some of its own members. Louisiana Sen. Mary Landrieu, running for reelection in one of the most closely watched Senate races this year, has already ruled out backing the bill because she has “little faith” in the State Department to use its allocated funding to help stem violence in Central America.

Landrieu voted against the procedural vote on Wednesday, as did North Carolina Sen. Kay Hagan, another vulnerable red-state Democrat. She said in a statement after the vote that the Senate legislation falls short in tackling the root causes of the illegal migration and targeting the criminal trafficking groups that are transporting the minors.

Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.), who voted to advance the legislation, said in a statement later Wednesday that he would reject the measure without “major changes.”

( Also on POLITICO: Christie: Dead man walking or comeback kid?)

“We need to include revisions to close loopholes in the 2008 immigration law so that there is the same deportation timetable for individuals from Central American countries as those from Mexico and Canada,” Manchin said. “The process should be the same for all of these countries.”

The Democratic defections on Wednesday, as well as a high number of Republican opposition on the procedural vote, stoked some uncertainty in the chamber on as senators were still casting their ballots.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), who opposes the Senate Democratic measure, initially voted to advance the bill. But once it looked like the legislation might collapse, he switched his vote to “no.”

( Also on POLITICO: Democrats ask: Where's FLOTUS?)

A McConnell aide said when the outcome of the procedural vote looked murky, “many of our members wanted to be on record in opposition to a bill that didn’t even include the minor reforms the president requested — not to mention any serious effort to secure the border.”

Eleven Republicans ultimately voted with most Democrats to advance the supplemental.

Of the $2.7 billion in emergency funding, about $1.2 billion is for the Department of Health and Human Services and $1.1 billion is for agencies within the Department of Homeland Security, which primarily oversees border and immigration enforcement. About $300 million is designated for the State Department and $124 million is for the Justice Department.
